user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of SHA1Input:
```c
static enum SHA1_RESULT
SHA1Input (struct SHA1Context *context, const unsigned char *message_array,
           unsigned length)
{
  if (! length)
  {
    return SHA1_RESULT_SUCCESS;
  }
  if (! context || ! message_array)
  {
    return SHA1_RESULT_NULL;
  }
  if (context->computed)
  {
    context->corrupted = 1;
    return SHA1_RESULT_STATE_ERROR;
  }
  if (context->corrupted)
  {
    return SHA1_RESULT_STATE_ERROR;
  }
  while (length-- && ! context->corrupted)
  {
    context->message_block[context->message_block_index++]
      = (*message_array & 0xFF);
    context->length_low += 8;
    if (context->length_low == 0)
    {
      context->length_high++;
      if (context->length_high == 0)
      {
        context->corrupted = 1;
      }
    }
    if (context->message_block_index == 64)
    {
      SHA1ProcessMessageBlock (context);
    }
    message_array++;
  }
  return SHA1_RESULT_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 applies specifically to uses of the <string.h> functions (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.). The provided code snippet contains no direct calls to any <string.h> functions anywhere else in the function, so those other lines (initial null checks, computed/corrupted flag checks, length_low/length_high updates, return statements, and the message_array++ increment) are not relevant to Rule 21.17 and do not need to be investigated for this rule. The only fragment that could lead to out-of-bounds accesses related to string-library usage is the loop that writes into context->message_block and triggers SHA1ProcessMessageBlock — that loop (and the block that calls SHA1ProcessMessageBlock) is reported above and should be inspected further (including the implementation of SHA1ProcessMessageBlock and the definitions/limits of message_block and message_block_index) to ensure no <string.h> functions are invoked in a way that can access beyond object bounds.
